importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the LEAP trial results were published and initial public health guidance for early peanut introduction in infants was issued, leading to a significant shift in medical practice and allergy outcomes.
When expanded guidelines for early allergen introduction were issued, resulting in a greater than 40% decline in peanut allergy diagnoses among children.
The most recent update to public health guidelines recommending early introduction of major allergens between 4 and 6 months of age, without prior screening.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 10-year period during which early peanut introduction recommendations have been implemented and demonstrated measurable public health benefits, including a decline in peanut allergy prevalence.

keyTakeAways: Peanut allergy rates in the U.S. have declined significantly since 2015, with a 27% drop after initial guidelines and over 40% decline after expanded recommendations in 2017.
About 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015 due to early introduction practices, as opposed to the previously reported 60,000 (corrected in the article).
Early allergen introduction—such as peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters—is now recommended between 4 and 6 months of age, without prior screening.

A landmark study by Gideon Lack and colleagues (the LEAP trial) showed that early exposure reduces future peanut allergy risk by over 80%, with protection lasting into adolescence in about 70% of cases.
Despite strong evidence, adoption of early introduction practices has been slow: only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists reported following the updated guidance in 2017.
The new research indicates that early allergen introduction is being adopted and is making measurable, real-world impacts on allergy prevalence.
Advocacy groups like Food Allergy Research & Education (FARE) support the shift, emphasizing that early exposure is a proven, evidence-based strategy to reduce food allergy incidence.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after a landmark study showed that introducing peanuts to babies as early as 4 months reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies by over 80%, new research confirms that this public health strategy has made measurable real-world impacts. Since 2015, the rate of peanut allergies in U.S. children under age 3 has declined by over 27%, and by more than 40% after expanded guidelines in 2017. The study, led by Dr. David Hill at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia and based on electronic health records, shows that about 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since the practice began. The original LEAP trial by Gideon Lack at King’s College London provided the scientific basis for these changes. Despite initial resistance and slow adoption—only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists followed the guidance—public health advocates and experts now see growing evidence that early allergen exposure is effective, safe, and widely beneficial. Recommendations now encourage parents to introduce small amounts of peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters between 4 and 6 months of age, without screening, as a proven way to reduce allergy incidence.
title: Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates, Study Shows
